channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Some Ukrainians Brace for Possibility of Russian Nuclear Strike
item.description: Fears of more severe retaliation grew after the attack on Russia’s sole bridge to Crimea. But U.S. officials have said they think the chances of Moscow’s using nuclear weapons are low.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Running from the scene of a Russian bombing in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday. Moscow responded to the assault on the Kerch Strait Bridge with a series of missile attacks across Ukraine.

item.title: Brittney Griner Is Struggling in Russian Prison, Her Lawyer Says
item.description: Facing nine years in prison in Russia, the U.S. basketball star is struggling emotionally and worried that a swap deal to release her may not materialize, according to one of her attorneys.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Kirill Kudryavtsev
item.media:description: Brittney Griner at a court outside Moscow in August. The United States has said that her detention and trial were politically motivated.

item.title: Labor Hoarding Could be Good News for the Economy
item.description: Employers have been burned by a labor shortage. Will that make them act differently if the economy slows down?
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek, Sydney Ember and Kim Raff
item.media:description: The dining room of Bistro Provenance, one of Chad Pritchard’s restaurants in Provo, Utah.

item.title: Quarterly Earnings Likely to Give Mixed Signals to Investors
item.description: Investors, weary of guessing where the Fed’s battle on inflation will take the economy, hope that third-quarter company earnings will bring clarity.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis and Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Nasdaq exchange. The stock market rallied at the beginning of the month before giving way to more selling, as optimism yielded to renewed concern over the economic outlook.

item.title: UK Markets Thrown Into Turmoil Once Again
item.description: Confusion over whether the central bank will end a debt-buying program as scheduled hit the values of the British pound and government debt.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Vivian Giang, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
item.category: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
item.media:credit: Yui Mok/Agence France-Presse, via Pool
item.media:description: Andrew Bailey, the governor of the Bank of England, was hit with a new bout of markets turmoil today.

item.title: Uvalde Shooting Investigation Miscast Blame For Delayed Police Response
item.description: The school police chief was singled out for blame, but a Times visual investigation found that scores of trained officers, including those from an elite Border Patrol unit, took many of the same steps.
item.dc:creator: Robin Stein and Alexander Cardia

item.title: Los Angeles Confronts Racial Divide Anew After Leak of Racist Comments
item.description: Scores of residents demanded that three City Council members resign — as did President Biden — over a secretly recorded conversation that involved racist insults and slurs.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Sarah Reingewirtz/The Orange County Register, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mike Bonin, a member of the Los Angeles City Council, shed tears on Tuesday as he spoke about the racist comments directed toward his son.

item.title: Hasidic School Is Breaking State Education Law, N.Y. Official Rules
item.description: Issued amid a lawsuit brought by a parent who left the community, the determination could pose a significant challenge to Hasidic Jewish schools.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro and Brian M. Rosenthal
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Yeshiva Mesivta Arugath Habosem, an all-boys Hasidic school in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is not complying with a state education law requiring private schools to offer basic secular studies.

item.title: FDA Authorizes Updated Covid Booster Shots For Kids 5 to 11
item.description: Regulators authorized the shots for older age groups in late August, but much of the general population appears either unaware or uninterested in them.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:credit: Kristopher Radder/The Brattleboro Reformer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Food and Drug Administration’s action will expand access to Pfizer’s shot to children as young as 5, and to Moderna’s shot to children 6 and older.

item.title: China’s Covid-Testing Strategy Comes Under Strain
item.description: Bills are piling up and infections are spreading, yet there are no signs that Beijing plans to rethink a cornerstone of its pandemic policy.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times

item.title: Misinformation Swirls in Non-English Languages Ahead of Midterms
item.description: More multilingual fact-checking groups are pushing back against misleading translations, manipulated images and outright lies that jump platforms and cross borders.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Nick Nguyen, a co-founder of Viet Fact Check, a group that offers in-depth context to help explain and debunk misinformation circulating in the Vietnamese American community.

item.title: Is Ron DeSantis as Strong a Potential Candidate as He Seems?
item.description: The Florida governor looks to be well positioned to head into a hypothetical presidential primary in 2024. But past Republican darlings rose just as fast — only to fall quickly.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: In polls, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida consistently rates as the second choice of Republican voters, behind former President Donald Trump but well ahead of any putative rivals.

item.title: Navy Report on SEAL Trainee’s Death Details Medics’ Failure to Help Him
item.description: Seaman Kyle Mullen’s death a few hours after completing the brutal Hell Week portion of the SEALs’ selection course raised broad concerns about how the course is run.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Behind a Migrant Shooting in Texas: A Warden and a Troubled Jail
item.description: Twin brothers in a small West Texas town were charged in the killing: one worked for the county; the other as warden of a private prison.
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times

item.title: Under the Skin of Jamie Lee Curtis
item.description: Whether it’s her return to her horror roots in “Halloween Ends” or her buzzy performance in “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” freedom is what the actress is after.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I feel all the feels, all the time,” Jamie Lee Curtis said.

item.title: American Culture Is Trash Culture
item.description: Our trash urges gave movies its musk, its fun, its hickies, its exercise. Where did it go?
item.dc:creator: Wesley Morris

item.title: Haiti Has Been a Plaything of Powerful Forces for Too Long
item.description: Haiti is in crisis. If the U.S. wants to help, it needs to get out of the way.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Polgreen
item.media:credit: Richard Pierrin/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters demanding the resignation of Ariel Henry, Haiti’s acting prime minister, set fires in the streets of Port-au-Prince this month.

item.title: With Attacks, Russia’s Putin Is Trying to Terrorize Ukrainians
item.description: Among Ukrainians, there is an almost palpable feeling that Russia is losing the war.
item.dc:creator: Margo Gontar
item.media:credit: Gleb Garanich/Reuters

item.title: The ‘Sleeping Giant’ That May Decide the Midterms
item.description: The choices made by Latino voters will be crucial to the outcome in a disproportionate share of Senate battleground states and key House races.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall
item.media:credit: Verónica G. Cárdenas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monica De La Cruz, the Republican candidate in Texas’ 15th Congressional District, at a rally in McAllen, Texas.

item.title: How Catholics Became Prisoners of Vatican II
item.description: As the Second Vatican Council turns 60, it looks unsuccessful and irreversible.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Girolamo Di Majo/Associated Press

item.title: Kanye Shows Where the Right’s Troll Politics Lead
item.description: Why conservatives can’t condemn his antisemitism.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Evan Vucci/Associated Press

item.title: In Defense of the Mom Group
item.description: An interview with Helena Andrews-Dyer about her new book, ‘The Mamas.’
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Eleanor Davis

item.title: A Nobel Prize for the Economics of Panic
item.description: The prize recognized important work explaining when and why financial markets implode.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by vanbeets and Bettmann via Getty Images

item.title: Abortion Bans Weigh on Republicans
item.description: Banning abortion is weighing on the party.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times

item.title: A Bridge, a Bomb and Putin’s Revenge
item.description: The Russian missile barrage on Ukraine reveals Moscow’s narrowing options.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Nina Feldman, Diana Nguyen, Mooj Zadie, John Ketchum, Liz O. Baylen, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Corey Schreppel
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage from a missile strike in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, this week. The rocket attacks left neighborhoods across the country battered and bloodied.

item.title: We Were Three
item.description: A story of lies, family, America and what Covid revealed, as well as what it destroyed. All three parts arrive on Thursday, Nov. 13.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Updike, Jenelle Pifer, Julie Snyder and Sophie Allison of Soccer Mommy
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Protests in Iran Spread, Including to Oil Sector, Despite Violent Crackdown
item.description: Human rights groups say at least 185 people have been killed and thousands injured or arrested, but demonstrations that began after the death of Mahsa Amini have continued nearly a month.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Jane Arraf
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: As Overdoses Soar, Rhode Island Embraces Drug Consumption Sites
item.description: It is the first state to legalize supervised drug consumption sites, which some addiction experts believe will help lower record overdose rates.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Cristina Ramsey, left, embracing Ashley Perry of Project Weber/Renew, days before Ms. Ramsey died from drug-related illnesses.

item.title: Hurricane Ian Survivors Have Allies in New Yorkers Who Went Through Sandy
item.description: Rockaways residents are sharing rebuilding tips, donating to nonprofit groups who helped them a decade ago and collecting gift cards.
item.dc:creator: Alyson Krueger
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Lynn and Elizabeth Duffy, sisters-in-law who live in the Rockaways and got through Hurricane Sandy almost 10 years ago, collected thousands in gift cards for Florida residents after Hurricane Ian.

item.title: Angela Lansbury, TV’s Favorite Sleuth on ‘Murder She Wrote,’ Dies at 96
item.description: She was a Hollywood and Broadway sensation, but she captured the biggest audience of her career as the TV sleuth Jessica Fletcher.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Lewis
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times

item.title: Flu Shot: What to Know About Side Effects, Protection and Timing
item.description: And everything else you’ve been wondering about this annual vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: New Study Strengthens the Link Between Exercise and Memory
item.description: Experts have long known that fitness is good for the brain. A recent paper connects different types of workouts with assorted improvements in memory.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: Does CBD Help With Insomnia?
item.description: The research is sparse, experts say, but there are some hints about how it could soothe you to sleep.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Gravel Biking is Getting Popular. Here’s How to Start.
item.description: A faster bicycle design with thicker tires is allowing cyclists to explore America’s 2.2 million miles of Here’s what you need to know about this new sport.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Singleton
item.media:credit: Alex Goodlett for The New York Times

item.title: How Do You Manage Omicron BA.5 Symptoms, Including a Sore Throat?
item.description: The longtime symptom of Covid is becoming more common, and sometimes more severe, with the dominant BA.5 subvariant.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Does Korean Cuisine Belong to Korea?
item.description: South Korea has sought to protect and enshrine its national dishes — while also exporting its wonders to the world.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan and David Chow
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
